newsitem.title: Armenia: Armenian leader moves troops in after riots.
newsitem.headline: Armenian leader moves troops in after riots.

text.p: Embattled Armenian President Levon Ter-Petrosyan moved the army into the capital Yerevan on Thursday in a crackdown on political opponents after violent clashes with riot police over Sunday's disputed election.

An interior ministry spokesman told Reuters six opposition members of parliament had been detained after the chamber, in which Ter-Petrosyan's ruling bloc dominate, voted to allow prosecutors to press charges against them.
Several were punched repeatedly by the deputies.
Opposition sources said opposition rival Vazgen Manukyan, sought by police under the clampdown, had gone into hiding.

The crisis erupted after Ter-Petrosyan, who has led the small Transcaucasian country of 3.5 million since independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, claimed election victory over Manukyan, a former prime minister.
International observers said they saw numerous cases of fraud being committed by Ter-Petrosyan officials both in the voting and counting process.
"Vazgen Manukyan is being sought," the spokesman said by telephone. Manukyan's whereabouts are not known and some of his associates say he is in hiding.
"He's gone underground," said a member of his National Democratic Union who did not want to be identified.
The crisis burst on a country suffering great economic hardship from confrontation with neighbouring Azerbaijan over the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh.
Conditions have eased in recent months but Armenia has suffered many winters of power cuts and shortages.

Unofficial results in the presidential vote gave Ter- Petrosyan 52 percent of the vote to 41 percent for Manukyan. Ter-Petrosyan needed 50 percent of the vote to avoid a second- round runoff against the former prime minister.
The clampdown followed violent clashes on Wednesday night between riot troops and thousands of Manukyan's supporters, who accuse the aloof 50-year old academic Ter-Petrosyan of rigging the poll.
Some protesters charged into parliament and beat the speaker and vice-speaker. Riot troops regained control after a nearly hour long battle with brick-hurling demonstrators.
An aide to Ter-Petrosyan told Reuters one soldier and one protester had been killed in the clashes and dozens were hurt.
Light tanks belching blue smoke sped along Yerevan streets while several thousand troops with Kalashnikov automatic rifles sealed off the centre.
Reuters Television producer Nino Ivanishvili witnessed a police raid on the headquarters of a small opposition party.
"Armed people in camouflage broke into the building. They were dragging people out and punching and kicking them," she said. She saw at least seven men dragged into a police van.
Reporters saw soldiers dispersing small groups gathering in a square where Manukyan's supporters used to rally. At least two people were beaten and taken away.
Ter-Petrosyan banned rallies and demonstrations in an early morning TV address, calling opposition politicians "mentally ill" people who had tried to stage a coup.
Ter-Petrosyan had been widely expected to win the poll, but Manukyan fought back strongly when several opposition groups withdrew their candidates and backed him.
Many people in the streets of Yerevan appeared shocked by the developments and disillusioned with Ter-Petrosyan, once undisputed leader of the tiny Caucasus state.
In Moscow, President Boris Yeltsin sent Ter-Petrosyan a congratulatory telegram and the Russian foreign ministry criticised the opposition supporters who took to the streets.
